description: President Trump, on his Inauguration Day, calls for tariffs on Mexico, Canada and China to be implemented Feb. 1.
Trump threatens 25% tariffs on Colombia after the country refused to accept U.S. planes with deported migrants.
President Gustavo Petro agrees to accept planes with deportees from the U.S.
Trump rescinds his threat of 25% tariffs on Colombia
Trump signs executive orders to implement tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China, set to start on Feb. 4.
Canada and Mexico threaten tariffs in response.
Canada and Mexico made moves to address Trump's concerns over border security and drug trafficking.
Trump delays tariffs on Canada and Mexico for 30 days
10% tariffs are put in place against China, the Postal Service bans packages from Hong Kong and China.
China issues retaliatory tariffs.
The Postal Service lifts its ban on packages from China because of the potential to create massive disruptions for online retailers and U.S. shoppers.
Trump says he will impose 25% tariffs on steel imports from all countries, and he raises aluminum tariffs from 10% to 25%.
Trump signs a memorandum that sets the stage for “reciprocal tariffs” to be announced on April 2.
Trump signs an executive order instructing the Commerce Department to investigate how copper imports threaten America's national security and economic stability.
Trump says he might give Canada and Mexico a reprieve on 25% tariffs on goods until April 2.
Trump reverses course and says they will go into effect March 4.
Trump signs an executive order to increase U.S. lumber production and orders a probe into potential lumber import tariffs.
Trump says that 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico will start on March 4 and told reporters there was “no room” for the countries to make a deal before they begin.
Trump levies 25% import tariffs on Canada and Mexico, as well as an additional 10% tariff on China.
China, Canada, and Mexico threaten retaliatory tariffs.
Trump grants automakers a reprieve from the 25% tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico until April 2.
Trump changes course and postpones 25% tariffs for goods covered by the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA).
China begins imposing tariffs on imports of U.S. farm products.
Canada announces a 25% surcharge on electricity exports from Ontario.
Trump announces plans to double tariffs — to 50% overall — on steel and aluminum from Canada, effective March 12.
Ontario agrees to suspend the surcharge.
Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum imports take effect.
The European Union and Canada, in response to Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum imports taking effect, hit back with their own retaliatory trade actions.
Trump backs off the double tariffs.
Trump threatens a 200% tariff on European alcohol.
Trump announces a 25% secondary tariff on all imports from countries that buy oil or gas from Venezuela, set to take effect on April 2.
Trump signs an executive order to impose 25% tariffs on all automobile imports effective April 3rd.
Trump declared 'Liberation Day' and announced sweeping tariffs.
The 25% tariff on all foreign made automobiles goes into effect.
The 'Liberation Day' tariffs, a 10% universal tariff on all imports from countries except Canada and Mexico go into effect.
The U.S. increased tariffs on Chinese goods to a cumulative 145%.
China raised its tariffs on U.S. goods to 125% and implemented non-tariff barriers, including export restrictions on rare earth elements.
Following market volatility, President Trump announced a 90-day pause on the newly imposed tariffs for all countries except China.
The administration announced that electronics such as smartphones and computers would be exempted from the reciprocal tariffs, though they might be subject to future Section 232 tariffs.
President Trump suggested that tariffs on Chinese imports might 'come down substantially.' due to concerns from the CEOs of major U.S. retailers.
President Trump signed an executive order to prevent the cumulative effect of multiple tariffs on the same goods, a practice referred to as 'stacking.'
The U.S. economy contracted by 0.3% in the first quarter of 2025, marking the first decline since early 2022.
